change.item: Finding aid revised to include contextual information about the homophobic descriptive language found within this collection. See the processing note for more information

repository.corpname: Special Collections Research Center, The George Washington University

did.abstract: Collection contains correspondence, research notes, articles, pamphlets, periodicals, news clippings, audio cassette tapes, banners, tee shirts, books, buttons (informational artifacts) and photographs. These materials range in date from 1967- 90 (bulk 1975 -85). It includes organizational and personal staff information about the Off Our Backs collective, a feminist journal; activities, informational, and promotional material for social and civic activism groups including Women's Liberation Zap Action Brigade,"ZAP," the American University's Women's Union, women's health, health clinics and various feminist conferences; memorabilia from the National Committee to Free Sharon Kowalski, interviews and lectures of feminist writers, and a variety of feminist and lesbian publications.

prefercite.head: Preferred citation
prefercite.p: Tacie Dejanikus papers, Special Collections Research Center, The George Washington University.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: In 2005, Tacie Dejanikus donated this collection to George Washington University.

userestrict.head: Restrictions on Use
userestrict.p: Some material may be copyrighted or restricted. It is the patron's obligation to determine and satisfy copyright or other case restrictions when publishing or otherwise distributing materials found in the collections.

bioghist.head: Historical or Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Tacie Dejanikus (1952 ca. -), a social and political activist, fought for women's and gay and lesbian rights as part of numerous organizations in the Washington, D.C. area. She wrote for feminist journals, participated in protest marches, and chaired social and politically minded organizations. Dejanikus lived in Chevy Chase, Maryland as a child at 7102 Ridgewood Avenue. In her late twenties, she joined the "Off Our Backs" collective, a D.C. based feminist journal. Over the next decade, her activities included interviewing various feminists and lesbians in D.C., writing for "Off Our Backs," and participating in protest activities throughout the area. Dejanikus and five other women from the Women's Liberation Zap Action Brigade were arrested on April 23, 1981, for disrupting a U.S. Senate hearing discussing the "Human Life Bill." All were released on bond for one hundred dollars and stood trial on July 6, 1981. Dejanikus continued her social and political activism, but professional disagreements compelled her to leave the "Off Our Backs" collective in 1985. In 1988 she helped form and co-chair the National Committee to Free Sharon Kowalski. She remained involved until 1991 when the Minnesota appeals court returned Sharon Kowalski to her partner Karen Thompson's custody. Throughout the course of her activities, Dejanikus protested for civil rights and health care concerns, including breast cancer, AIDS, and birth control. These papers document her and other's activities giving researchers a window into feminist and lesbian concerns as debated and protested in the Washington, D.C. area.

scopecontent.head: Collection Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: This collection contains correspondence, research notes, articles, pamphlets, periodicals, news clippings, audio cassette tapes, banners, tee shirts, books, buttons (informational artifacts) and photographs. These materials range in date from 1967- 90 (bulk 1975 -85). It includes organizational and personal staff information about the Off Our Backs collective, a feminist journal; activities, informational, and promotional material for social and civic activism groups including Women's Liberation Zap Action Brigade,"ZAP," the American University's Women's Union, women's health, health clinics and various feminist conferences; memorabilia from the National Committee to Free Sharon Kowalski, interviews and lectures of feminist writers, and a variety of feminist and lesbian publications.

Please note: each box in this collection contains material from many different series. This explains, for example, why the box listing for series 4 starts with box 1, but folder 22. The previous folders in box 1 are from different series and are listed elsewhere in the finding aid.

arrangement.head: Collection Organization
arrangement.p: Organized into five series: Off Our Backs, Social and Civic Activism, The National Committee to Free Sharon Kowalski, Interviews and Lectures, and Publications.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This finding aid was revised in 2022 to address outdated descriptive language. During that revision, description was not edited or removed, but additional information was provided to add context. This archival object Box 1 Folder 47 has a Processing Information note to explain the revision.
To view the finding aid prior to this revision: The Tacie Dejanikus papers pre-revision finding aid March 2022

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains correspondence, statements, memoranda, notes, publications, and a tee-shirt. They range in date from 1973- 85, and represent Dejanikus' involvement in the Off Our Backs Organization. This series includes select publications of "Off Our Backs" from 1973-84. Official and personal materials from the organization are placed before "Off Our Backs" publications.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains news clippings, pamphlets, memoranda, notes, correspondence, and buttons (informational artifacts). They range in date from 1975-90 and represent a wide range of women's, lesbian and gay rights issues including the activist organization ZAP, health care concerns, American University's Women's Union, and protests against pornographic films.

did.unittitle: Feminist and Lesbian Literature and Activities

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Contains court summons for Dejanikus and other related items to her arrest.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Contains 4 trays of buttons (informational artifacts). Topics include protesting for gay rights, breast cancer awareness, AIDS awareness, presidential candidates, and domestic violence. Includes one button from the National Committee to Free Sharon Kowalski.

did.unittitle: The National Committee to Free Sharon Kowalski

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series consists of an signed book, certificate, banners, tee shirts and buttons (informational artifacts) from the National Committee to Free Sharon Kowalski co-chaired by Tacie Dejanikus from 1988-91. In 1983 Sharon Kowalski was permanently disabled in a car accident and a legal battle ensued over guardianship between Donald and Della Kowalski, Sharon's parents, and Karen Thompson, Sharon's partner. Supporters of Karen Thompson formed The National Committee to Free Sharon to support Thompson's efforts in removing Sharon from her parent's custody and placing her under Thompson's own care. The court would place Sharon Kowalski under Thompson's care in December of 1991.

National Committee to Free Sharon Kowalski

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains notes, newspaper clippings, photographs, and audio cassette tapes. This includes news clippings, notes, and interviews with Michelle Cliff regarding her book, "Claiming An Identity They Taught Me To Despise." Also included are interview notes with Stephanie Liu concerning her thoughts on being a lesbian and personal correspondence, photographs, and news clippings sent by Liu to Dejanikus after Liu moved to Hong Kong.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The materials in this series includes periodicals, guides, a coloring book, a music songbook, informational booklets from 1967-90. The majority of these publications are from feminist, lesbian, or women's groups

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: The term Dyke has historically been used as a slur. For this archival object it is the title of a publication and therefore will not be removed. The Homosaurus, an international linked data vocabulary of Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual, Transgender, and Queer (LGBTQ) terms, defines the term as "A largely reclaimed slur common in the U.S. that may be used to refer to lesbians who embrace a masculine style of presentation or lesbian political activists in general; only use for individuals who self-identify as dykes." The GW SCRC recognizes that this terminology may be offensive to some.
To view the finding aid prior to this revision: The Tacie Dejanikus papers pre-revision finding aid March 2022
